top_categories.workout_context: Transcordilleras’s colombian andes, south american gravel demands rapid power changes — surge over obstacles, settle on smoother sections, repeat for hours.
Transcordilleras rewards athletes who can hold sustained power without blowing up — threshold is the engine that drives everything above Zone 2.
Over-unders train the lactate clearance you’ll need at Transcordilleras when surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding hard.
Racing Transcordilleras isn’t just fitness — it’s pacing, fueling, and executing when conditions deteriorate. This workout practices the race itself.
At 120 miles, Transcordilleras punishes athletes who haven’t trained their body to produce power when glycogen runs low.
Transcordilleras’s colombian andes mountain gravel and competitive field demand explosive aerobic capacity — the ability to respond to surges without blowing up.
Transcordilleras’s 15,000ft of climbing demands seated and standing versatility — the ability to change climbing style as gradient and fatigue dictate.
The G-Spot zone (88–92% FTP) is where you’ll spend the hardest sustained miles of Transcordilleras. Make this intensity feel like home.
Every session at Transcordilleras intensity builds on this aerobic foundation — the endurance base is the soil everything else grows in.
Critical power determines how long you can sustain above-threshold efforts at Transcordilleras — a higher CP means more time in the red before failure.
Low-cadence force work builds the muscular strength for Transcordilleras’s 15,000ft of climbing — especially the grinding, low-speed ascents.
At 120 miles, Transcordilleras rewards a massive aerobic engine. This volume work builds the fat-oxidation capacity that keeps you moving when glycogen runs low.

race_overlay.nutrition: Target 60–80g carbs/hour for Transcordilleras’s 120 miles. Start fueling within the first 30 minutes — early fueling prevents late-race collapse. Bonking at mile 60 is a nutrition failure, not a fitness failure.
race_overlay.altitude: Transcordilleras with 15,000ft of climbing, much of it above 8,000ft demands altitude preparation. Arrive 5–7 days early for acclimatization. Expect 5–15% power reduction at altitude. Increase iron intake 4 weeks out. Hydrate aggressively — altitude increases fluid loss by 20–40%. High altitude.
race_overlay.terrain: Highly technical terrain at Transcordilleras demands practice on similar surfaces. Ride colombian andes mountain gravel at race-day cadence weekly. Expect: colombian andes, south american gravel, regional event. Practice cornering, descending, and power delivery on unstable surfaces. Dial in tire pressure before race week — 5 PSI wrong costs you 15+ minutes over 120 miles.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on Gravel Specific, TT Threshold, and Over Under to prepare you for 120 miles of colombian andes mountain gravel in Colombian Andes, Colombia.
